anno-designer.synopsis: A program that lets you create and export building layouts for the Anno series of games.

chain-of-responsibility.synopsis: A software design pattern that allows an event to be handled by a chain of objects.

facade.synopsis: A software design pattern that provides a simplified interface to a larger body of code.

adapter.synopsis: A software design pattern that allows the interface of an existing class to be used as another interface.

ci-cd.synopsis: A software development practice where developers integrate code into a shared repository frequently, and then automatically build and test the software.

nuget.synopsis: A package manager for the Microsoft development platform, including .NET.

oop.synopsis: A programming paradigm based on the concept of <q>objects</q>, which can contain data and code.

nunit.synopsis: An open-source .NET unit testing framework, focused on simplicity and ease of use.

uml.synopsis: A graphical modeling language used to describe, specify, construct, and document software systems.

anno2070.synopsis: Anno 2070 is a city-building and economic simulation game, with real-time strategy elements. It is the 5th game of the Anno series. It was released on <time datetime="2011-11-17">17 November 2011</time> on Windows.

apache2.synopsis: A free and open-source cross-platform web server software.

bash.synopsis: A shell program and command language supported by the <abbr title="Free Software Foundation">FSF</abbr> and first developed for the <abbr title="GNU is Not Unix">GNU</abbr> Project by Brian Fox.

blender.synopsis: Blender is a free and open-source 3D computer graphics software tool set.

buildcraft.synopsis: Minecraft videogame mod that focuses on adding building and automation features to the game. This mod was created by developer SpaceToad.

c.synopsis: A general-purpose programming language. It was created in the 1970s by Dennis Ritchie and Ken Thompson. Despite its age, it remains very widely used and influential.

chartier--le-goff-marius.synopsis: Marius Chartier--Le Goff was born in <time datetime="2005">2005</time> and is a student in computer science at the IUT of Lannion. He wishes to continue his studies until he becomes an engineer.

cities-skylines.synopsis: A <time datetime="2015">2015</time> city-building game developed by Colossal Order and published by Paradox Interactive. The game is a single-player open-ended city-building simulation.

cmake.synopsis: In software development, CMake is cross-platform free and open-source software for build automation, testing, packaging and installation of software by using a compiler-independent method.

cpp.synopsis: A high-level, general-purpose programming language created by Danish computer scientist Bjarne Stroustrup.

csharp.synopsis: A general-purpose high-level programming language supporting multiple paradigms.

css.synopsis: A style sheet language used for specifying the presentation and styling of a document written in a markup language such as HTML or XML.

csv.synopsis: A text file format that uses commas to separate values, and newlines to separate records.

docker.synopsis: A set of platform as a service (PaaS) products that use OS-level virtualization to deliver software in packages called containers.

dotnet.synopsis: A free and open-source, managed computer software framework for Windows, Linux, and macOS operating systems.

doxygen.synopsis: A documentation generator and static analysis tool for software source trees. When used as a documentation generator, Doxygen extracts information from specially-formatted comments within the code. When used for analysis, Doxygen uses its parse tree to generate diagrams and charts of the code structure. Doxygen can cross reference documentation and code, so that the reader of a document can easily refer to the actual code.

dreamfinity.synopsis: <q cite="https://dreamfinity.org">We present you the most modern and innovative Minecraft server: the Dreamfinity project! Our unique servers combine all the best modes, fresh features and gameplay features available for playing in Minecraft on the network. For many years, we have been analyzing the needs of a variety of players and can confidently say: you will like it!</q>

ebnf.synopsis: A <abbr title="Backus-Naur Form">BNF</abbr> extension created by Niklaus Wirth in 1996. This language expresses formal grammars, which are notably used in compiler design.

eclipse.synopsis: Eclipse is an <abbr title="IDE">integrated development environment</abbr> used in computer programming. It contains a base workspace and an extensible plug-in system for customizing the environment. It is the second-most-popular IDE for Java development

figma.synopsis: A collaborative web application for interface design.

galacticraft.synopsis: Minecraft videogame mod that adds a space dimension to the game, allowing players to travel through space, explore new planets and build space colonies. This mod was created by developer Micdoodle8.

gcov.synopsis: Gcov is a source code coverage analysis and statement-by-statement profiling tool. Gcov generates exact counts of the number of times each statement in a program is executed and annotates source code to add instrumentation. Gcov comes as a standard utility with the GNU Compiler Collection (GCC) suite.

github.synopsis: A developer platform that allows developers to create, store, manage and share their code.

gitlab.synopsis: GitLab is a DevOps software package that can develop, secure, and operate software. GitLab includes a distributed version control based on Git, including features such as access control, bug tracking, software feature requests, task management, and wikis for every project, as well as snippets.

gloomaps.synopsis: A simple online visual sitemap tool.

go.synopsis: Go is a statically typed, compiled high-level programming language designed at Google by Robert Griesemer, Rob Pike, and Ken Thompson. It is syntactically similar to C, but also has memory safety, garbage collection, structural typing and CSP-style concurrency.

gprof.synopsis: Gprof is a performance analysis tool for Unix applications. It used a hybrid of instrumentation and sampling and was created as an extended version of the older "prof" tool. Unlike prof, gprof is capable of limited call graph collecting and printing.

html.synopsis: The standard markup language for documents designed to be displayed in a web browser. It defines the content and structure of web content.

immersive-engineering.synopsis: Minecraft videogame mod that aims to add a more realistic and immersive gaming experience by focusing on engineering, construction and automation. This mod was created by developer BluSunrize.

industrialcraft-2.synopsis: Minecraft videogame mod that focuses on adding new industrial and technological features to the game. This mod was created by developer Alblaka.

inno-setup.synopsis: A free software script-driven installation system created in Delphi by Jordan Russell. The first version was released in 1997.

java.synopsis: A high-level, class-based, object-oriented programming language that is designed to have as few implementation dependencies as possible.

javafx.synopsis: A software platform for creating and delivering desktop applications, as well as rich web applications that can run across a wide variety of devices. JavaFX has support for desktop computers and web browsers on Microsoft Windows, Linux (including Raspberry Pi), and macOS, as well as mobile devices running iOS and Android, through Gluon Mobile.

javascript.synopsis: A programming language and core technology of the Web, alongside HTML and CSS.

json.synopsis: An open standard file format and data interchange format that uses human-readable text to store and transmit data objects consisting of attribute–value pairs and arrays (or other serializable values).

kervadec-matteo.synopsis: Mattéo Kervadec is a first-year BUT student in the Computer Science stream at the IUT in Lannion. He has a baccalaureate with the specialties Mathematics and NSI obtained at the high school Sainte-Anne in Sainte-Anne-d'Auray. He is passionate about tennis and cinema, both in films and video games. He is also interested in computer software development.

lua.synopsis: A lightweight, high-level, multi-paradigm programming language designed primarily for embedded use in applications.

make.synopsis: In software development, Make is a command-line interface software tool that performs actions ordered by configured dependencies as defined in a configuration file called a makefile. It is commonly used for build automation to build executable code (such as a program or library) from source code. But, not limited to building, Make can perform any operation available via the operating system shell.

markdown.synopsis: A lightweight markup language for creating formatted text using a plain-text editor.

matplotlib.synopsis: Matplotlib is a plotting library for the Python programming language and its numerical mathematics extension NumPy. It provides an object-oriented API for embedding plots into applications using general-purpose GUI toolkits like Tkinter, wxPython, Qt, or GTK.

mermaid.synopsis: JavaScript-based diagramming and charting tool that renders Markdown-inspired text definitions to create and modify diagrams dynamically.

minecraft.synopsis: A <time datetime="2011">2011</time> sandbox game developed by Mojang Studios and originally released in <time datetime="2009">2009</time>.

mousepad.synopsis: Mousepad is a simple text editor for the Xfce desktop environment. Mousepad aims to be an easy-to-use and fast editor.

mysql.synopsis: An open-source relational database management system.

nasm.synopsis: The Netwide Assembler (NASM) is an assembler and disassembler for the Intel x86 architecture. It can be used to write 16-bit, 32-bit (IA-32) and 64-bit (x86-64) programs. It is considered one of the most popular assemblers for Linux and x86 chips.

numpy.synopsis: NumPy is a library for the Python programming language, adding support for large, multi-dimensional arrays and matrices, along with a large collection of high-level mathematical functions to operate on these arrays.

pandas.synopsis: Pandas (styled as pandas) is a software library written for the Python programming language for data manipulation and analysis. In particular, it offers data structures and operations for manipulating numerical tables and time series. It is free software released under the three-clause BSD license.

pascal.synopsis: An imperative and procedural programming language, designed by Niklaus Wirth as a small, efficient language intended to encourage good programming practices using structured programming and data structuring.

pdf.synopsis: Portable Document Format (PDF), standardized as ISO 32000, is a file format developed by Adobe in 1992 to present documents, including text formatting and images, in a manner independent of application software, hardware, and operating systems.

pgsql.synopsis: A free and open-source relational database management system.

php.synopsis: A general-purpose scripting language geared towards web development, created in 1993.

powershell.synopsis: A task automation and configuration management program from Microsoft, consisting of a command-line shell and the associated scripting language.

python.synopsis: A high-level, general-purpose programming language. Its design philosophy emphasizes code readability with the use of significant indentation.

replit.synopsis: An American start-up and an online IDE that allows creating online programming projects called repls.

rolland-stanislas.synopsis: Stanislas Rolland is a BUT computer science student at the IUT of Lannion. Before joining this training, he obtained his baccalaureate with honors with the specialties Mathematics and <abbr title="Numérique Sciences Informatiques">NSI</abbr>.

rust.synopsis: Rust is a general-purpose programming language emphasizing performance, type safety, and concurrency. It enforces memory safety, meaning that all references point to valid memory. It does so without a traditional garbage collector; instead, both memory safety errors and data races are prevented by the "borrow checker", which tracks the object lifetime of references at compile time.

sass.synopsis: A preprocessor scripting language that is interpreted or compiled into CSS.

scheme.synopsis: A dialect of the Lisp family of programming languages. Scheme was created during the 1970s at the <abbr title="MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory">MIT AI</abbr> Lab).

smalltalk.synopsis: A purely object oriented programming language (OOP) that was originally created in <time datetime="1972">1972</time> for educational use.

spyder.synopsis: Spyder is an open-source IDE specifically designed for scientific programming in the Python language. It is part of the Anaconda distribution but can also be installed independently.

sql.synopsis: A domain-specific language used to manage data, especially in relational database management systems.

sql-workbench.synopsis: A database engine written in the C programming language.

sqlite.synopsis: A DBMS-independent, cross-platform SQL query tool.

survivalworld.synopsis: <q cite="https://top-serveurs.net/minecraft/survivalworld-65355b32ec669">SurvivalWorld is the reference for Minecraft Survival servers throughout the French-speaking world! Meet up with your friends, or come and make some more, to survive in the vast plains of our worlds.</q>

svg.synopsis: An XML-based vector image format for defining two-dimensional graphics, having support for interactivity and animation.

task-dialog.synopsis: A dialog box that can be used to display information and receive simple input from the user. Like a message box, it is formatted by the operating system according to parameters you set. However, a task dialog has many more features than a message box.

tkinter.synopsis: A Python binding to the Tk GUI toolkit. It is the standard Python interface to the Tk GUI toolkit.

toe-paolo.synopsis: Paolo Vito Toé is a student in BUT Informatique at the IUT of Lannion. His path pushes him to constantly improve, because IT is one of his great passions. Born in the United States and raised in several different countries, he is also passionate about foreign cultures. In addition to his studies, he is passionate about reading and creating games.

visual-paradigm.synopsis: A versatile software development tool that provides a range of features to support different aspects of software development life cycle (SDLC). It's primarily known for its UML (Unified Modeling Language) modeling tools, which help developers, architects, and analysts to visualize, specify, construct, and document software systems.

visual-studio.synopsis: An <abbr title="Integrated Development Environment">IDE</abbr> developed by Microsoft. It is used to develop computer programs.

vs-code.synopsis: A source-code editor developed by Microsoft for Windows, Linux, macOS and web browsers.

winforms.synopsis: A free and open-source graphical class library included as a part of Microsoft .NET, .NET Framework or Mono.

wizard.synopsis: Despite that wonderful, whimsical name, wizards are not really a special form of user interface, and they have only a particular range of utility. Wizards are used to perform multi-step tasks.

wpf.synopsis: A free and open-source user interface framework for Windows-based desktop applications.

xml.synopsis: A markup language and file format for storing, transmitting, and reconstructing arbitrary data.

zig.synopsis: An imperative, general-purpose, statically typed, compiled system programming language designed by Andrew Kelley in <time datetime="2015">2015</time> as a successor to C.
